bibl.title: Letter from Henry W. Woltman to John H. Andrus, March 23, 1938

div1.p: Woltman gives Andrus medical advice, suggesting that neither yellow fever nor arthritis are the cause of his condition.

div1.head: Letter from Henry W. Woltman to John H. Andrus, March 23, 1938
div1.opener:
yellow fever
March 23, 1938
Mr. J. H. Andrus,
805 Cooper Street,
Camden, New Jersey.
My dear Mr. Andrus:
div1.p:
Dr. Hench kindly referred your recent letter to
me and I have read it with interest and sympathy. I have
had no personal experience with yellow fever but I have read
of no complications involving the nervous system that made
their appearance long after the attack of fever ran a
progressive course or suggested the picture you described.
As Dr. Hench said, the production of neurologic symptoms
of the intensity you describe which point to some involve-
ment of the spinal cord secondary to arthritis of the spine
is most unusual and one would naturally be led to suspect
the presence of some other coexistant illness. Just what
this may be I could not venture to suggest on the basis of
the information before me. Very likely Dr. Hench will
discuss the matter with me on his return and I am sure he
will write to you.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Henry W. Woltman, M.D. HWW:RD
